channel.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
channel.description:
http://torrentfreak.com/4chan-ddos-takes-down-mpaa-and-anti-piracy-websites-100918/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed:+Torrentfreak+(Torrentfreak)
Following a call to arms yesterday, the masses inhabiting the anonymous 4chan boards have carried out a huge assault on a pair of anti-piracy enemies. The website of Aiplex Software, the anti-piracy outfit which has been DDoSing torrent sites recently, is currently down having been DDoS’d. They are joined in the Internet wasteland by the MPAA’s website, also currently under huge and sustained attack.

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Erj:

We should go and DDoS Moparscape.

That would probably be bad for moparisthebest.com as well, you know, considering they live on the same server…

Read full topic

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:60, topic:360765”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=457062.msg3348927#msg3348927 date=1285094111]
I’d argue that people are brainwashed into liking what the industry wants them to by using trends as their primary weapon.
[/quote]

It’s a perfect mix of greed and peer pressure. You’re not ‘cool’ if you don’t drink certain drinks, visit certain shops, buy certain gadgets, wear branded clothes, or listen to mainstream music. Everybody thinks they are free, but in reality were getting closer and closer to a society where corporations are in complete control. I’d say that within 10-20 years, when our parents’ generation has lost it’s last bits of influence (they are the last bastion, although you could say that they are being influenced too), we’ll be uniform zombies.

We’ll be going to school wearing our Diesel/Tommy Hilfiger/‘insert random brand here’ clothes. Our backpack will contain an iPad, MacBook and a few bottles of Coca-Cola. While on the bus, we’ll be listening to Sony’s hits on our iPod. We’ll check up on the latest trends using our iPhone. And during lunch we’ll be eating the latest addition to McDonald’s ‘healthy’ McFakeingredients line.

‘O brave new world!’[/quote]
thats funny cuz literally no one gives a shit about designer names where i live

Read full topic
item.source: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Speljohan:

I’d argue that people are brainwashed into liking what the industry wants them to by using trends as their primary weapon.

It’s a perfect mix of greed and peer pressure. You’re not ‘cool’ if you don’t drink certain drinks, visit certain shops, buy certain gadgets, wear branded clothes, or listen to mainstream music. Everybody thinks they are free, but in reality were getting closer and closer to a society where corporations are in complete control. I’d say that within 10-20 years, when our parents’ generation has lost it’s last bits of influence (they are the last bastion, although you could say that they are being influenced too), we’ll be uniform zombies.

We’ll be going to school wearing our Diesel/Tommy Hilfiger/‘insert random brand here’ clothes. Our backpack will contain an iPad, MacBook and a few bottles of Coca-Cola. While on the bus, we’ll be listening to Sony’s hits on our iPod. We’ll check up on the latest trends using our iPhone. And during lunch we’ll be eating the latest addition to McDonald’s ‘healthy’ McFakeingredients line.

‘O brave new world!’

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:58, topic:360765”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=457062.msg3348922#msg3348922 date=1285092490]
The majority of consumers don’t give a shit about artistic quality. Market value represents how many people like a song, and it only makes sense that the music industry should judge bands in this way. Why should certain original and artistic songs be promoted if hardly anyone likes them?
[/quote]

I hope they do care about the quality of the music they listen to. But I guess my hope is in vain, looking at the crap being spewed on MTV and the like nowadays.

The music industry has to look in the future. They have to think along the lines of “people are going to like that, so lets promote it” instead of “people like that, so let’s alter it a bit and earn more money from it”.[/quote]I’d argue that people are brainwashed into liking what the industry wants them to by using trends as their primary weapon.

Read full topic
item.source: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

xx matty xx:

The majority of consumers don’t give a shit about artistic quality. Market value represents how many people like a song, and it only makes sense that the music industry should judge bands in this way. Why should certain original and artistic songs be promoted if hardly anyone likes them?

I hope they do care about the quality of the music they listen to. But I guess my hope is in vain, looking at the crap being spewed on MTV and the like nowadays.

The music industry has to look in the future. They have to think along the lines of “people are going to like that, so lets promote it” instead of “people like that, so let’s alter it a bit and earn more money from it”.

Read full topic

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

But until the music industry finds a way to distribute their music in a fair way, and stops judging a band on their market value and not on their artistic quality, I won’t buy any music from big labels. And I doubt that day will ever come.

The majority of consumers don’t give a shit about artistic quality. Market value represents how many people like a song, and it only makes sense that the music industry should judge bands in this way. Why should certain original and artistic songs be promoted if hardly anyone likes them?

Read full topic

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Mopman:

(or listen to it on the radio exclusively)

The next big hit for Dutch copyright ‘protectors’: charge everyone who has a radio turned on in their shop/workplace/wherever because they ‘use it as a tool to satisfy customers, which justifies a fee!’ Or what about this: Charge every consumer, including children, that puts a homemade video on YouTube containing a song €130,-!

I’m not primarily pirating music because it’s free, it’s also a form of saying fuck you to those assholes who try to milk every song and every movie, while the artists get nothing. To back that statement: In 2009 Videma (responsible for copyrights of movies) collected €19,4 million, of which only €6,3 million went to the artists. Now that’s a hefty markup.

@Speljohan: I too find the whole piracy scene a big pile of overreacting crap, especially those ‘Pirate parties’. Even for a one-issue party they are too narrow-minded, and unable to make a statement. Luckily, they didn’t get a seat in our Parliament. But until the music industry finds a way to distribute their music in a fair way, and stops judging a band on their market value and not on their artistic quality, I won’t buy any music from big labels. And I doubt that day will ever come.

Read full topic
item.source: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

I got turned on to iTunes due to the iTunes gift cards I’ve been receiving, and the resulting library and I have to say. It isn’t that bad anymore, I do buy stuff off there now. Not so much music, because I just don’t listen to much music anymore, but TV shows. But aside from the terrible Windows client, the iTunes service itself is alright now.

I think the prices for music are fine too.

Read full topic

depends on genre i guess, i listen to music that dosent often get major label attention, so i dont sacrifice anything by using indie labels, they ARE the music i want to listen to

Most of the artists who play the music I listen to are dead already, so I generally just rip the music from the 33s or cassette tapes that I have from them or buy on-the-cheap.

But people prefer to listen to the music they’ve been brainwashed to like, not shitty independent artists without government support

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:48, topic:360765”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=457062.msg3348876#msg3348876 date=1285084759]

A quick google found me this:
http://www.bit-tech.net/news/2009/01/07/itunes-to-drop-drm/1

This part would piss me the hell off if I ever bought anything from itunes though:

There’s good news and bad news for anyone who has already built up an extensive library of purchased iTunes content: the good news is that Apple will be providing functionality to convert locked-down content to DRM-free versions; the bad news is that, according to CNet, a fee of 30¢ will be charged per song in addition to the money already paid for the purchase. For users who have a large collection, this could soon add up to a significant sum.

So, good move for iTunes though, now it isn’t a COMPLETE waste of money. Now if they started offering FLAC downloads it might be interesting.

except they never will, they’ll offer ALAC if anything
[/quote]

The article says they also offer mp3 now, so it doesn’t seem like FLAC would be completely outside the realm of possibility like it used to be.[/quote]
iPods dont even support FLAC why would they sell it?

Read full topic
item.source: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:47, topic:360765”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=457062.msg3348867#msg3348867 date=1285083447]
A quick google found me this:

bit-tech.net

iTunes to drop DRM | bit-tech.net

Apple has made a surprising announcement at this year's MacWorld - all songs available on iTunes are to be made DRM free as of this quarter.

This part would piss me the hell off if I ever bought anything from itunes though:

There’s good news and bad news for anyone who has already built up an extensive library of purchased iTunes content: the good news is that Apple will be providing functionality to convert locked-down content to DRM-free versions; the bad news is that, according to CNet, a fee of 30¢ will be charged per song in addition to the money already paid for the purchase. For users who have a large collection, this could soon add up to a significant sum.

So, good move for iTunes though, now it isn’t a COMPLETE waste of money. Now if they started offering FLAC downloads it might be interesting.
[/quote]
except they never will, they’ll offer ALAC if anything[/quote]

The article says they also offer mp3 now, so it doesn’t seem like FLAC would be completely outside the realm of possibility like it used to be.

Read full topic

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:39, topic:360765”]Maybe. I just don’t believe that media such as music should have the price tag that it does.
$1 per song is a bit expensive, especially when you aren’t free to do what you please with it.[/quote]

Difference of opinion I guess. $1 seems incredibly cheap to me. You seem to forget that the artists have to eat.

Beatport is closer to $2 a track and I always considered that reasonable, although they had Wave + 320kb MP3 from day 0 and never ever had restrictions on what you could do with music, because their target audience is DJs who I assume are more conscious of music purchases vs. average consumer given that its their living or w/e

EDIT: incidentally a small minirant

i know everyones constantly saying this “hurr you should support the indies and not the major labels” but it really is true… the “indie” distribution networks have been doing it right since day 1… all ya gotta do is stop listening to sony’s stuff folks (or listen to it on the radio exclusively)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest

@moparisthebest wrote:

A quick google found me this:

bit-tech.net

iTunes to drop DRM | bit-tech.net

Apple has made a surprising announcement at this year's MacWorld - all songs available on iTunes are to be made DRM free as of this quarter.

This part would piss me the hell off if I ever bought anything from itunes though:

There's good news and bad news for anyone who has already built up an extensive library of purchased iTunes content: the good news is that Apple will be providing functionality to convert locked-down content to DRM-free versions; the bad news is that, according to CNet, a fee of 30¢ will be charged per song in addition to the money already paid for the purchase. For users who have a large collection, this could soon add up to a significant sum.

So, good move for iTunes though, now it isn’t a COMPLETE waste of money. Now if they started offering FLAC downloads it might be interesting.

item.title: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Mopman:

which nobody would ever do

Haha.

[quote=“Speljohan, post:37, topic:360765”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=457062.msg3348479#msg3348479 date=1285027177]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=457062.msg3348390#msg3348390 date=1285021181]

[quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=457062.msg3348338#msg3348338 date=1285019473]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=457062.msg3348261#msg3348261 date=1285015941]

the only reason speljohan is saying to buy software is because he supports indie games.
[/quote]i couldnt care less about games cos it is easy to make features that only work with internet validation, but music is a completely different story.

Of course – just look at what Ubisoft was subject to when they released Assassin’s Creed 2. :rolleyes:

Sure they can do it, but thankfully there’s such a negative stigma surrounding such approaches that many companies should either overlook the idea or back down on it before release.
[/quote]How is that even relevant to what i said? There are plenty of good ways to make non-annoying DRMs that cannot be cirumvented.

You must know something none of the top game producing programmers know, since all they can make is annoying DRMs that can easily be circumvented.

There isn’t any protection that can be made that can’t be circumvented.
[/quote]server-side features… but they generally dont do this cos they live in countries where bandwidth costs more money than gold
[/quote]because you can’t reverse engineer the game and remove validation, or make your own auth server
[/quote]i said server-side FEATURES. this would involve writing their own server software altogether, resulting in players not being part of the official community.[/quote]
For a single player game like Assassin’s Creed, there’s no real value in being ‘part of a community’. In fact, I think the majority of people wouldn’t bother.
At the end of the day, they just want the game.

[quote=“Mopman, post:32, topic:360765”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=457062.msg3347979#msg3347979 date=1284974697]
I’d probably consider iTunes cards if the songs were valued at $0.20 - $0.30 each.

haha you cheap cunt :D[/quote]
Maybe. I just don’t believe that media such as music should have the price tag that it does.
$1 per song is a bit expensive, especially when you aren’t free to do what you please with it.

Read full topic
item.source: 4chan DDoS Takes Down MPAA and Anti-Piracy Websites
